description: A Company Network with DMZ protected by two firewalls and implemented through a Docker container network.
goal:
Configuration of two firewalls in a Company Network with DMZ using the rules of IPTABLES tool.

Security rules test by analyzing the log file generated by the ULOGD2 daemon.
solution:
Setup

Configuration of the external firewall - firewall1 (for firewall2 is the same).

Enter in firewall1 container and insert the following rules:

1. First of all we have to delete the default rules in the chains

$ iptables -F

$ iptables -F -t -nat

2. Then we delete the empty non-standard chains

$ iptables -X

3. Set to DROP the default rules in the chains (instead of FORWARD we can also use both INPUT or OUTPUT):

$ iptables -P FORWARD DROP

Up so far, if you try to enter in the cliente1 container and ping the web-server (192.1.2.2), you can notice that it is unreachable.

Insert these rules (in both firewalls) in order to accept the connections with the services in the DMZ and avoid that clients on the external network could reach the internal hosts (and viceversa):

$ iptables -t filter -A FORWARD -i eth0 -o eth1 -m state --state NEW,ESTABLISHED,RELATED -j ACCEPT

$ iptables -t filter -A FORWARD -i eth1 -o eth0 -m state --state ESTABLISHED,RELATED -j ACCEPT

Ulogd2

In order to verify the correct working of the rules, we can add before and after them two more rules that allows us to log the traffic that pass thorugh the firewall. We have already set up the ulogd2 daemon which has the purpose to log the results. The sintax is:

$ iptables -A FORWARD -j NFLOG --nflog-prefix="FORWARD Log rule_name: "

Then (after the attack) go into the firewall and follow the path /var/log/ulog.

Open the file syslogemu.log with nano and see the logs. They can be used also to inspect the traffic that pass thorugh the firewall for example using an IDS.

Rules

We can now define more strict rules for the two firewalls, that we can insert inside the firewall1 (the same for firewall2):

1. The following rules are about the drop of all the INVALID packets (like tcp packets built with no-standard flags)

$ iptables -A FORWARD -m state --state INVALID -j DROP

$ iptables -A FORWARD -p tcp --tcp-flags ALL ACK,RST,SYN,FIN -j DROP

$ iptables -A FORWARD -p tcp --tcp-flags ALL ALL -j DROP

$ iptables -A FORWARD -p tcp --tcp-flags ALL NONE -j DROP

Let's try to verify the success of the rules, go to the cliente1 and use the command:

hping3 -d 120 --xmas -p 80 192.1.2.2

The tool hping3 allow us to force a Xmas Attack.

LOG XMAS

Attack Example: Syn Flood

Now we can insert some rules to avoid the syn flood attack. It is a type of DoS attack which aims to make a server unvailable to legitimate traffic by consuming all available server resources. By repeatedly sending initial connection request (SYN) packets, the attacker is able to overwhelm all available ports on a targeted server machine, causing the targeted device to respond to legitimate traffic sluggishly or not at all.

1. First of all we create a new chain: SYN_FLOOD

$ iptables -N SYN_FLOOD       

2. Go to the SYN_FLOOD chain if the packet is tcp and has the flag syn=1
$ iptables -A FORWARD -p tcp --syn -j SYN_FLOOD       

3. The packet is dropped if the limits (not more than 1 packet/sec) in the rule are not respected:
$ iptables -A SYN_FLOOD -m limit --limit 1/s -j RETURN
$ iptables -A SYN_FLOOD -j DROP

Then you can try the attack writing in the cliente1 shell the command:

hping3 -c 15000 -d 120 -S -w 64 -p 80 --flood --rand-source 192.1.2.2

You can check the logs in the file syslogemu.log:

IMMAGINE LOG SYN FLOOD

You can try to simulate and check several different attack scenario like Ping of Death and others...

 

Other useful commands:

$ iptables -L CHAIN_NAME

to show the list of rules present in a chain

$ iptables -D CHAIN_NAME rule_number

to delete a specific rule in a chain
author: em.me
